questions.text:
Match the following cell markers with their corresponding cells:

 


	
		
			
			Cell marker
			
			
			Cell
			
		
		
			
			i) Cytokeratin
			
			
			a) Astrocytes
			
		
		
			
			ii) Vimentin
			
			
			b) Skeletal muscle cell
			
		
		
			
			iii) Desmin
			
			
			c) Mesenchymal cell
			
		
		
			
			iv) Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)
			
			
			d) Epithelial cell
questions.solution:
Cell markers are used to identify different types of cells.

 

Cell marker

Cell

Cytokeratin

Epithelial cell

Vimentin

Mesenchymal cell.

Desmin

Skeletal muscle cell

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)

Astrocytes

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to be seen if a patient is infused with 3% NaCl?

choices.text: Water shifts from ICF to ECF

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

3% NaCl is a hypertonic solution; the changes seen will be that of hypertonic volume expansion.

Disorder

Examples

Effects

Hyperosmatic Volume Expansion
  • Excessive infusion of hypertonic saline.
  • Increase in ECF volume.
  • Increased plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ICF to ECF
  • Decreased plasma protein concentration
  • Increased arterial blood pressure

Hyposmotic Volume Expansion
  • SIADH
  • Increase in ECF volume.
  • Increase in ICF volume.
  • Decrease in plasma osmolarity.
  • No change in hematocrit.
  • Decreased plasma protein concentration.

Isosmotic Volume Expansion
  • Infusion of isotonic NaCl
  • Increase in ECF volume.
  • No change in ICF volume.
  • No change in osmolarity.
  • Decreased hematocrit.
  • Decreased plasma protein concentration.

Hypertonic Volume Expansion" data-author="NA" data-hash="7848" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="262" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/nyCGzU1L7keWvGnol06d1744010158.png" width="500" />

Isotonic Volume Expansion" data-author="NA" data-hash="7846" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="262" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/FukfpvgzNSUeF5TrVkMF1744009943.png" width="500" />

questions.text: Which of the following does this Darrow-Yannet diagram (Solid line represent the controlled condition and broken red-line indicates new-steady state condition) represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

The Darrow-Yannet diagram shows isosmotic volume contraction; an example of that is diarrhoea.

Darrow-Yannet Diagram:

  • It helps to understand the plasma osmolarity and volume alterations in various diseases.
  • The volume is plotted in x-axis and plasma osmolarity in y-axis.
  • Broken lines indicate the flow of water between compartments driven by osmotic gradients, reflecting passive movement in response to changes in solute concentrations.
  • A normal Darrow-Yannet Diagram is shown below:

Disorder

Examples

Effects

Isosmotic volume contraction
  • Diarrhoea
  • Vomiting
  • Haemorrhage
  • Burns
  • Decrease in ECF and plasma volumes
  • Increased plasma protein concentration
  • Increased hematocrit
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure

Hyposmotic volume contraction
  • Adrenocortical insufficiency
  • Gastric secretions loss
  • Decreased plasma volume
  • Decreased ECF and plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ECF to ICF
  • Cellular swelling
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure

Hyperosmotic volume contraction
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Excessive sweating
  • Alcoholism
  • Fever
  • Decrease in ECF and plasma volumes
  • Increased ECF and plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ICF to ECF
  • Increased hematocrit
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure.

questions.text: Oxygen moves from the alveoli into the blood across the alveolar-capillary membrane. Which of the following best describes this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Simple Diffusion


 

Explanation:

Oxygen moves from an area of higher concentration in the alveoli to an area of lower concentration in the blood through simple diffusion, which follows Fick's law of diffusion.

 

Types of diffusion:

 

 

 

Simple diffusion

Facilitated diffusion (Option A)
  • Move from high to low solute concentration (downhill transport)
  • It does not require energy.
  • Not require carrier protein (channel protein may or may not be present)
  • No saturation: more concentration leads to a higher rate of transport.
  • Fick's law: Rate (J) = D.A.∆C/x
    • D: Diffusion constant.
    • A: Surface area of diffusion.
    • X: Thickness of the membrane.
    • ∆C: Concentration difference between membranes (most important determinant).
  • Movement of molecules across a membrane via carrier protein.
  • No expenditure of energy.
  • For example, glucose is transported by all types of GLUT.
  • Saturation is achieved after a certain point called the plateau.
  • The maximum transport rate occurs at the plateau or saturation point, called maximum (Tm)

Active transport requires energy to move substances against their concentration gradient, which is not the case for the passive movement of oxygen from the alveoli to the blood. (Option C)

 

Osmosis refers to the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane from an area of lower solute concentration to an area of higher and does not describe the movement of gases like oxygen. (Option D)

questions.text: While studying insulin secretion in pancreatic beta cells, a researcher scientist observes the fusion of the insulin-stored vesicles with the cell membrane to release insulin into the extracellular space in response to blood glucose levels. Which of the following statements about this process is correct?

choices.text: Exocytosis is a passive process that does not require energy.
During exocytosis, vesicles fuse with the lysosome to release their contents.
Exocytosis involves the transport of substances out of the cell via vesicle fusion with the cell membrane.
Exocytosis is primarily used to uptake nutrients and molecules from the extracellular environment.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Exocytosis involves the transport of substances out of the cell via vesicle fusion with the cell membrane.

 

Explanation:

Exocytosis can be constitutive or non-constitutive.

 

Constitutive

Non-constitutive
  • Direct secretion of vesicles outside the cell.
  • Vesicles that do not move directly outside the cell are moved to a particular portion of the cell, where they are temporarily stored.
  • During their temporary storage, pre-processing of these vesicles happens.
  • As a result, more refined protein vesicles are produced. This is known as non-constitutive exocytosis.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Exocytosis is a passive process that does not require energy.

  • Exocytosis is an active process that requires energy in the form of ATP.
  • This energy is needed for the vesicle fusion with the cell membrane and the subsequent release of its contents.

 

During exocytosis, vesicles fuse with the lysosome to release their contents.

  • This statement is incorrect because they fuse directly with the cell membrane, not with lysosomes.
  • Lysosomes are involved in intracellular digestion, not in the exocytotic release of substances.

 

Exocytosis is primarily used to uptake nutrients and molecules from the extracellular environment.

  • Exocytosis expels substances from the cell, not to uptake them.
  • Endocytosis is the process used to take in nutrients and molecules from the extracellular environment.

questions.text: Select the correct statements regarding endocytosis:

choices.text: Pinocytosis involves ingesting solid particles into the cell by budding small vesicles from the cell membrane.
Phagocytosis is a type of endocytosis that involves the ingestion of liquid into the cell.
Receptor-mediated endocytosis is a non-selective process where molecules are ingested into the cell without needing receptors..
All forms of endocytosis require ATP for the vesicle formation process

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All forms of endocytosis require ATP for the vesicle formation process.

 

Explanation:

 

All forms of endocytosis require ATP for the vesicle formation process.

 

Endocytosis:

 

  • Endocytosis is an active transport process that requires energy in the form of ATP to form and move vesicles within the cell.
  • Three types of endocytosis:

 

Pinocytosis
(Option: A)
  • Referred to as "cell drinking".
  • Uptake of extracellular fluids by budding small vesicles from the cell membrane.

Phagocytosis
(Option: B)
  • Referred to as "cell eating".
  • Engulfs large particles such as pathogens or cellular debris. into the cell.

Receptor-mediated endocytosis

(Option: C)
  • Specific molecules are ingested into the cell by binding to specific receptors on the cell surface.
  • Clathrin-mediated endocytosis:
    • Triskelion shape protein (3 heavy and 3 light chains).
    • Presents on the surface of the cell membrane
    • Provides a coating on the surface of the vesicle with the help of dynamin protein.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding facilitated diffusion is false?

choices.text: It does not require ATP expenditure.
Involved transport protein is stereospecific and follows saturation kinetics.
Diffusion of ammonia in collecting ducts is a type of facilitated diffusion.
Molecules move down the chemical gradient from high to low concentration.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diffusion of ammonia in collecting ducts is a type of facilitated diffusion.


 

Explanation:

 

Diffusion of ammonia in collecting ducts to excrete ammonium ions into urine is a type of non-ionic diffusion. It occurs at the level of GIT and kidney for the transportation of weak acids or bases.

 

Facilitated diffusion does not require energy expenditure and uses transport (carrier) proteins that follow saturation kinetics, stereospecificity and competition. (Option A and B)

 

Molecules move from areas of high to low concentration (down their chemical gradient), and cations move to negatively charged areas whereas anions move to positively charged areas (“down” their electrical gradient). (Option D)

questions.text: Oxygen moves from the alveoli into the blood across the alveolar-capillary membrane. Which of the following best describes this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Simple Diffusion


 

Explanation:

Oxygen moves from an area of higher concentration in the alveoli to an area of lower concentration in the blood through simple diffusion, which follows Fick's law of diffusion.

 

Types of diffusion:

 

Simple diffusion

Facilitated diffusion (Option A)
  • Move from high to low solute concentration (downhill transport)
  • It does not require energy.
  • Not require carrier protein (channel protein may or may not be present)
  • No saturation: more concentration leads to a higher rate of transport.
  • Fick's law: Rate (J) = D.A.∆C/x
    • D: Diffusion constant.
    • A: Surface area of diffusion.
    • X: Thickness of the membrane.
    • ∆C: Concentration difference between membranes (most important determinant).
  • Movement of molecules across a membrane via carrier protein.
  • No expenditure of energy.
  • For example, glucose is transported by all types of GLUT.
  • Saturation is achieved after a certain point called the plateau.
  • The maximum transport rate occurs at the plateau or saturation point, called maximum (Tm).

Active transport requires energy to move substances against their concentration gradient, which is not the case for the passive movement of oxygen from the alveoli to the blood. (Option C)

 

Osmosis refers to the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane from an area of lower solute concentration to an area of higher and does not describe the movement of gases like oxygen. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the statements below is false?

choices.text: An example of symport is the absorption of glucose into the small intestine.
Antiport maintains sodium-potassium balance in cells.
Secondary active transporter always depends on the primary active transporter in the symport.
The symport mechanism in myocardial cells is blocked by digitalis, which increases contraction force.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The symport mechanism in myocardial cells is blocked by digitalis, which increases contraction force.

 

 

Explanation:

Digitalis blocks Antiport mechanism.

Symport

Antiport
  • It involves the movement of two molecules in the same direction
  • Transport requires the binding of more than one substance to the transport protein.
  • It is important in glucose absorption in the intestines. (Option A)
  • Glucose and sodium move together, with sodium following the concentration gradient and glucose against the concentration gradient.
  • The secondary active transporter is always dependent on the primary active transporter. (Option C)
  • For example, SGLT depends on the Na-K- ATPase pump to remove Na molecules from inside the cell.
  • It involves the movement of two molecules in opposite directions
  • Exchanges one substance for another
  • It is crucial for maintaining sodium-potassium balance in cells and basal metabolism. (Option B)
  • E.g. Sodium-Calcium exchanger
  • Calcium moves inside and outside the cell in uphill transport (against the gradient); hence, sodium moves inside the cell along the concentration gradient.
  • Na-K-ATPase prevents intracellular sodium accumulation.
  • Na-K-ATPase is blocked by Ouabain or

digitalis, increases calcium accumulation inside the myocardial cells and leads to increased force of contraction. (Option D)

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding tight junctions.

choices.text: Tight junctions are involved in endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation.
Tight junctions allow the passage of small molecules and ions between cells through the paracellular pathway.
Tight junctions are composed of proteins such as occludin, junctional adhesion molecules, and claudins.
Tight junctions are primarily found in the apical margins of cells in connective tissue.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tight junctions are primarily found in the apical margins of cells in connective tissue.


 

Explanation:

 

Tight junction: Sealing strand composed of a long row of transmembrane adhesion proteins embedded in the two interacting plasma membranes.

 

  • The extracellular domains of these proteins join directly to one another to occlude the intercellular space.
  • Tight junctions are primarily found in apical margins of epithelia cells, not connective tissue (Option D)
  • Tight junctions actually limit the permeability of epithelial cells to ions and solutes, thus regulating the overall ion and solute flux rather than increasing it.
  • Tight junctions are important to endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation.(Option A ruled out)
  • Tight junctions permit the passage of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.(Option B ruled out)
  • Occludin, junctional adhesion molecules, and claudins are the main families of transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junctions.(Option C ruled out)

 

Intercellular junctions:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Na⁺-K⁺ ATPase is false?

choices.text: It is an electrogenic pump with a coupling ratio of 3Na+:2K+
The α subunit has intracellular Na⁺ and ATP-binding sites
The α subunit contains the phosphorylation site at Asp 376
Its activity is enhanced by ouabain and digitalis glycosides

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Its activity is enhanced by ouabain and digitalis glycosides


 

Explanation:

Na, K ATPase catalyses the hydrolysis of ATP to adenosine diphosphate(ADP) and uses the energy to extrude three Na+ from the cell and take two K+ into the cell for each molecule of ATP hydrolysed.

Features:

 

  • Its activity is inhibited by ouabain and related digitalis glycosides used to treat heart failure.
  • It is an electrogenic pump with a coupling ratio of 3Na+:2K+
  • It is a heterodimer made up of α subunit of weight 1,00,000 and β subunit of weight 55,000.
  • The α subunit has intracellular Na⁺ and ATP-binding sites.
  • The α subunit contains the phosphorylation site at Asp 376.
  • Both α and β subunits are heterogeneous, with multiple isoforms (α₁, α₂, α₃, β₁, β₂, β₃) present in different tissues.
  • Thyroid hormone, aldosterone, and aldosterone increase the pump activity whereas dopamine in the kidney inhibits the pump activity.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered downhill transport?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Passive transport


 

Explanation:

 

Passive Transport (Option B)

Active Transport (Option A ruled out)

Primary Active Transport (Option C ruled out)

Secondary Active Transport (Option D ruled out)

Moves molecules down their gradient (downhill transport) from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration

 

 

Moves molecules against their gradient (uphill transport) from an area of lower concentration to an area of higher concentration.

 

 

It uses ATP directly to move molecules against their gradient from an area of lower concentration to an area of higher concentration.

 

It uses energy from the gradient created by primary active transport

 

Primary active transport creates an ion gradient (e.g., Na+ gradient by the Na+/K+ pump)

↓

Na+/K+ pump uses ATP to pump Na+ out of the cell (against its gradient)

↓

A high concentration of Na+ outside the cell

↓

Uses the Na+ gradient to transport other molecules (e.g., glucose) into the cell

It does not require energy

Requires energy (ATP)

Requires energy (ATP)

Energy is indirectly required from the ATP used by the Na+/K+ pump

Example: Diffusion of oxygen (O2) across a cell membrane

Example: Sodium-potassium pump (Na+/K+ pump)

Example: Calcium pump (Ca2+ pump)

Example: Glucose-sodium co-transport (SGLT)

Downhill transport

Not downhill transport

Not downhill transport

Not downhill transport

questions.text: Which of the following Connexin mutations is associated with cataracts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Connexin 50


 

Explanation:

 

Connexin 46 and 50 mutations lead to cataracts.

 

Connexons:

  • Structures that form the gap junction present in the membrane of each cell.
  • 1 Connexon = 6 connexins

 

Connexins:

  • Protein subunits, which together form connexons.
  • They surround a channel.
  • When lined up with the channel in the corresponding connexon in the adjacent cell, it permits substances to pass between the cells without entering the ECF.

 

Mutated Connexins and associated diseases:

 

Mutated Connexin

Disease

Connexin 30

Clouston syndrome

Connexin 30.3 and 31

Erythrokeratoderma Variabilis

Connexin 26,30 and 31

Inherited deafness

Connexin 36

Predisposition to Myoclonic Epilepsy

Connexin 37

Predisposition to Arteriosclerosis

Connexin 46 and 50

Cataract

Connexin 40

Idiopathic Atrial fibrillation

Connexin 32

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

Connexin 26 (GJB2): Associated with non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss, NOT cataracts. Most common cause of inherited deafness. (Option A)

Connexin 30 (GJB6) :Also linked to hearing loss, often in conjunction with Connexin 26. No established link to cataracts.(Option B)

Connexin 40 (GJA5): Found in the heart, particularly in the atria. Associated with cardiac conduction abnormalities (e.g., atrial fibrillation), not cataracts. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches a junction type with its key features?

choices.text: Tight Junctions - Provide mechanical strength and link cytoskeletons of adjacent cells.
Adherens Junctions - Create a seal between adjacent cells and prevent the passage of molecules through intercellular space.
Desmosomes - Form channels between cells, allowing direct passage of small molecules and ions.
Gap Junctions - Enable rapid communication and coordination, forming channels between cells for electrical signal propagation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gap Junctions - Enable rapid communication and coordination, forming channels between cells for electrical signal propagation.


 

Explanation:

 

Cell-to-Cell Interactions:

 

Mechanism

Key Components

Physical Contact
  • Tight junctions
  • Adherens junctions
  • Desmosomes
  • Gap junctions

Chemical Messengers
  • Hormones
  • Neurotransmitters growth factors

ECM Interaction
  • Proteins polysaccharides

 

Cellular Junctions:

 

Type

Key Features

Tight Junctions (Option A ruled out)
  • Create a seal between adjacent cells.
  • Prevent the passage of molecules through intercellular space.
  • It is essential for maintaining tissue barriers and regulating substance movement across epithelia.

Adherens Junctions (Option B ruled out)
  • Provide mechanical strength.
  • Link cytoskeletons of adjacent cells.

Desmosomes (Option C ruled out)
  • Similar to adherens junctions in function.
  • Provide additional mechanical stability.

Gap Junctions (Option D)
  • Form channels between cells.
  • Allow direct passage of small molecules and ions.
  • Enable rapid communication and coordination (e.g.- electrical signals in cardiac muscle).


 

Cell Adhesion Molecules (CAMs):

 

Type

Role

Integrins
  • Cell-to-cell and cell-to-ECM adhesion
  • Involved in cell signaling, migration, and proliferation

Immunoglobulins
  • Cell-to-cell adhesion
  • Immune recognition

Cadherins
  • Calcium-dependent
  • Mediate cell-to-cell adhesion
  • Crucial in tissue morphogenesis

Selectins
  • Transient cell-to-cell adhesion in the bloodstream
  • Enable white blood cells to bind to endothelial cells and migrate to inflammation sites

 

Extracellular Matrix (ECM):

  • Provides structural support, regulates cell behavior, and influences tissue development.

 

Chemical Messengers:

  • Mechanism: Cells release and receive chemical messengers (hormones, neurotransmitters, growth factors).
  • Function: Bind to specific receptors on target cells, triggering intracellular signaling pathways to regulate cellular processes.

questions.text: A patient with metastatic breast cancer is prescribed paclitaxel. What effect does paclitaxel have on microtubules?

choices.text: At low concentrations, paclitaxel promotes rapid polymerisation and mitotic spindle formation.
At high concentrations, paclitaxel destabilizes microtubules, causing rapid disassembly and mitotic arrest.
At high concentrations, paclitaxel stabilizes microtubules, increasing polymer mass and inducing bundle formation.
Paclitaxel shifts equilibrium towards tubulin dimers, promoting microtubule dynamics and mitosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) At high concentrations, paclitaxel stabilizes microtubules, increasing polymer mass and inducing bundle formation.


Explanation:

Paclitaxel primarily exerts anti-tumour effects by stabilising microtubules and altering their dynamics in a concentration-dependent manner.

Paclitaxel:

 

DEFINITION
  • An anti-tumour agent which is effective against several cancers

MECHANISM

Binds to the β-subunit of tubulin in a 1:1 stoichiometry

↓

Causes stabilisation of microtubules (Options B and D)

CONCENTRATION-DEPENDENT EFFECTS

High Concentrations (Option C)

Low Concentrations
  • Microtubule polymer mass increases
  • Induces microtubule bundle formation in interphase cells
  • Suppresses microtubule dynamics without altering polymer mass (Option A)
  • Blocks mitosis by stabilising spindle microtubules

EFFECT ON CELLS

Sensitive Cells

Resistant Cells
  • Mitotic Block
  • Induces cell death
  • Model 1: Contain "hypo stable" microtubules with equilibrium shifted towards tubulin dimers
  • Model 2: Equilibrium is shifted towards highly dynamic microtubules

At low concentrations, paclitaxel promotes rapid polymerisation and mitotic spindle formation (Option A): While paclitaxel can affect microtubules even at low concentrations, it does not promote normal spindle function. It inhibits proper mitosis, not support it.

At high concentrations, paclitaxel destabilizes microtubules, causing rapid disassembly and mitotic arrest (Option B): Exactly opposite of what paclitaxel does. It stabilizes, not destabilizes microtubules. Drugs like vincristine or colchicine destabilize microtubules—not paclitaxel.

Paclitaxel shifts equilibrium towards tubulin dimers, promoting microtubule dynamics and mitosis (Option D): Again, the opposite of paclitaxel’s action. Paclitaxel inhibits microtubule dynamics, which are essential for mitosis.It shifts the equilibrium toward polymerized microtubules, not tubulin dimers.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the term "milieu intérieur"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Extracellular fluid

 

Explanation:

 

"Milieu Intérieur" - The stable internal environment within an organism, maintained despite external changes.

 

Extracellular fluid (ECF):

 

Definition
  • Fluid outside the cells
  • Constitutes about one-third of the total body water.

Function

It functions as the body's internal environment, or milieu intérieur since it contains the essential ions and nutrients necessary for cell survival.

Types
  • Interstitial Fluid: Fills the spaces between cells
    • Lymph
    • Tissue fluid
  • Intravascular Fluid: The fluid within the blood vessels, mostly Plasma.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about microtubules is true?

 

i) Microtubules form the cytoskeleton of organelles such as cilia and nerve axons, providing structural integrity and rigidity.

 

ii) Microtubules function as channels allowing the passage of small molecules and ions between cells.

 

iii) Microtubules play a dynamic role in cell division, movement, and intracellular transport by acting as conveyor belts for vesicles, granules, and organelles like mitochondria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) All are correct except (ii)


 

Explanation:

 

Microtubules:

 

Role

Explanation

Key Points

Cellular Scaffold

Provides structural integrity as part of the cell cytoskeleton.
  • Constructed from polymerised tubulin
  • Provides rigidity and shape to cell parts

Cytoskeleton of Organelles

Forms cytoskeletons of cilia, nerve axons, and mitotic spindles.
  • Important for cell division
  • Maintains organisation and compartmentalisation

Dynamic Roles in Cells

Involved in cell division, movement, and intracellular transport.
  • Acts as conveyor belts
  • Facilitates movement of vesicles, granules, and organelles within the cell

questions.text: Which biological membrane has the highest protein-to-lipid ratio?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mitochondrial inner membrane

 

Explanation:

 

Biological membrane

Protein (%)

Lipid (%)

Ratio

Plasma membrane

~50

~50

~ 1.1

Mitochondrial inner membrane

~75

~25

~ 3.1

Myelin sheath

~15 to 30

~70 to 85

~ 0.17 to 0.4

questions.text: Which statements about the cell membrane are correct?

choices.text: Sphingolipids form channels for water and water-soluble substances, aiding diffusion.
Cholesterol acts as a receptor for peptide hormones, triggering intracellular processes.
Peripheral proteins penetrate the lipid bilayer and actively transport substances.
Glycocalyx contributes to negative surface charge, cell adhesion, and immune reactions.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glycocalyx contributes to negative surface charge, cell adhesion, and immune reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Components of cell membrane:

 

Membrane Lipids:

 

Component

Description

Function

Phospholipids
  • Most abundant
  • Arranged in a bilayer with hydrophilic heads outward and hydrophobic tails inward.
  • A barrier to water-soluble substances, allowing fat-soluble substances to pass.

Sphingolipids
  • It is found in smaller amounts, especially in nerve cells.
  • Protection
  • Signal transmission
  • Adhesion sites for extracellular proteins

Cholesterol
  • Embedded in the lipid bilayer.
  • Influences membrane permeability and fluidity

 

Membrane Proteins:

 

Type

Description

Function

Integral Proteins

Span the entire lipid bilayer, protruding on both sides.
  • Transport: Form channels for water and ions.
  • Selective Diffusion: Facilitate specific substance diffusion
  • Carrier Proteins: Bind and transport substances, including active transport
  • Enzymes: Catalyze reactions
  • Receptors: Bind ligands to trigger intracellular processes

Peripheral Proteins

Attached to the inner or outer surface, not spanning the lipid bilayer.
  • Function as enzymes or regulators of substance transport.

 

Membrane Carbohydrates - Glycocalyx:

 

Component

Description

Function

Glycoproteins

Proteins with carbohydrate chains
  • Protection
  • Cell recognition
  • Signaling.

Glycolipids

Lipids with carbohydrate chains
  • Cell recognition
  • Communication.

Proteoglycans

Carbohydrate-rich compounds that are attached to the outer cell surface
  • Structural support
  • Interaction with the extracellular matrix.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital after experiencing severe dehydration due to prolonged vomiting and diarrhoea. His symptoms include dry mouth, low blood pressure, and rapid heart rate. Which of the following fluids can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Normal saline


 

Explanation:

 

Among the given options, normal Saline is the only isotonic solution. Only isotonic solutions should be used in the case of dehydration.

 

Isotonic solution:

 

Definition
  • Solution of equal concentration as that of red cell content & plasma.
  • RBCs remain intact on using it.

Examples

  • 0.9%NaCl (Normal Saline).
  • 5% glucose.
  • 10% mannitol.
  • 20% urea.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Body fluids
			
			
			Indicators used to measure it
			
		
		
			
			1. Extracellular fluid
			
			
			a. Inulin
			
		
		
			
			2. Plasma
			
			
			b. Aminopyrine
			
		
		
			
			3. Total body water
			
			
			c. Evans blue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b


 

Explanation:

 

Indicators used to measure body fluids:

 

ECF

Plasma volume

Interstitial fluid

ICF
  • Inulin
  • Radioactive Inulin
  • Chlorine
  • Bromine
  • Mannitol
  • Sucrose
  • Sulphate
  • Thiosulphate
  • Thiocyanate
  • Ferrocyanide
  • Evans Blue Dye
  • Radio-iodinated Human Serum Albumin (RISA)
  • Radio-iodinated Gamma Globulin
  • Fibrinogen
  • Radio-isotopes of Phosphorus
  • Iron
  • Chromium
  • It cannot be measured directly.
  • It is calculated using ECF - Plasma volume.
  • It cannot be measured directly.
  • It is calculated using TBW - ECF.
  • Total body water (TBW) is measured by:
    • Deuterium oxide (D2O).
    • Tritium oxide.
    • Aminopyrine.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of transcellular fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Transcellular Fluid:

 

Definition
  • Fluid in the lumen of structures lined by epithelium.

Examples
  • Fluid in the secretion of exocrine digestive glands
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
  • Pleural, peritoneal, synovial and pericardial fluids
  • Intraocular (aqueous and vitreous humor) fluids
  • Bile
  • Luminal fluids of the gut
  • Fluid in the cochlea and kidney tubules

Volume

  • 1.5% of body weight
  • About 1L.

questions.text: The plasma volume of a person is 4 liters and the hematocrit is 20%, what is the blood volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 5 litres

 

Explanation:

 

  • Blood Volume = Plasma Volume/(1-Hematocrit)

= 4/(1-20%)

= 4/(1-0.2)

= 4/0.8

= 5 litres

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding body fluids is true?

choices.text: ICF makes up 40% of body weight
ECF makes up 40% of body weight
ICF makes up 33% of body weight

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ICF makes up 40% of body weight

 

Explanation:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are examples of feed-forward control systems in physiology?


	The clotting cascade rapidly amplifies clot formation after vascular injury.
	Muscles adjust in advance for standing or moving.
	Increased heart rate before starting of physical activity.
	Sweating in response to increased body temperature.
	The smell of food triggers digestive enzyme secretion.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2, 3, 5

 

 

Explanation:

 

Feed-forward control system/anticipatory control system:

 

  • Predicts changes and initiates responses to prevent deviations from the desired state before they occur
  • Pre-empts disturbances, enhancing efficiency and stability by preparing in advance to maintain homeostasis

 

Example

Mechanism

Physiological Benefit

Anticipatory Regulation of Blood Glucose

Secretion of insulin in response to the sight or smell of food

Prevents a sharp spike in blood glucose levels after eating.

Heart Rate Adjustment during Exercise

Brain signals increase heart rate and blood flow to muscles before activity.

Ensures muscles receive adequate oxygen and nutrients from the start of exercise.

Digestive Enzyme Secretion

The cephalic phase triggers the secretion of digestive enzymes and gastric juices.

Prepares the digestive system to efficiently break down and absorb nutrients.

Thermoregulation

Anticipation of cold triggers vasoconstriction. Thermoregulation also has negative feedback component.

Maintains core body temperature, preventing a drop that could affect enzymatic activities.

Postural Control

Muscles adjust in advance for standing or moving.

Prevents falls and injuries by maintaining balance and coordination.

Feed-Forward Inhibition by the Cerebellum

Granular cells excite basket cells, which inhibit Purkinje cells, refining motor commands before they occur.

Ensures smooth, precise motor control by preventing excessive or unwanted movements.

questions.text: A person moved from his hometown to Delhi to appear for an exam. The initial respiratory rate was 12 breaths per minute. After arriving at the exam center, the respiratory rate increased to 20 breaths per minute. The respiratory center corrected this to 16 breaths per minute. Calculate the regulation factor for the respiratory rate.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 0.5

 

Explanation:

 

The regulation factor checks the accuracy of the control system.

 

Regulation Factor = Change with control system / Change without control system

  • Initial Respiratory Rate: 12 breaths/minute
  • Post-Flight Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/minute
  • Corrected Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths/minute

 

Correction Achieved by the Respiratory Center = Change with control system = (20−16 = 4 breaths/minute)

 

Total Correction Needed = Change without control system = (20−12 = 8 breaths/minute)

 

  • Regulation Factor = Change with control system / Change without control system = 4/8 = 0.5

questions.text: A patient’s blood glucose level in a steady-state condition before a heavy lunch was 90 mg/dL. After lunch, the blood glucose level increased to 180 mg/dL. Insulin secretion from the pancreas reduced the blood glucose level to 120 mg/dL. Calculate the gain of the glucose regulatory mechanism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) -2

 

Explanation:

Correction achieved by the insulin secretion is: (180 mg/dL - 120 mg/dL = 60 mg/dL)

Error compared to the initial state is: (120 mg/dL - 90 mg/dL = 30 mg/dL)

 

Gain = Correction Achieved / Error Remaining


Substituting the values:
Gain = 60 mg/dL / 30 mg/dL = 2


Since the gain is negative in the context of this glucose regulatory mechanism (because an increase in blood glucose results in a decrease in gain):


Gain = -2

 

The degree of effectiveness with which a control system maintains constant conditions is determined by the gain of negative feedback.

questions.text:
Which of the following operates based on a negative feedback mechanism?

 


	Thyroid hormone regulation
	Blood glucose regulation
	Blood clotting cascade
	Nerve Signal Propagation
	Temperature regulation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2, and 5

 

Explanation:

Thyroid hormone, blood glucose, and temperature regulation follow a negative feedback mechanism.

Negative feedback mechanism: The body responds to a change by initiating actions that counteract the change, aiming to restore equilibrium.

 

Examples of negative feedback mechanisms:

System

Stimulus

Response

Effect

Body Temperature

Temperature deviation

Sweating/shivering, vasodilation/constriction

Restores normal temperature

Blood Glucose

High/low blood glucose

Insulin/glucagon release

Normalises blood glucose levels

Thyroid Hormones

High/low thyroid hormones

TSH release adjustment

Maintains hormone balance

Blood Pressure

High/low blood pressure

Heart rate and vessel adjustment

Restores normal blood pressure

Calcium Homeostasis

High/low blood calcium

PTH/calcitonin release

Normalises blood calcium levels

Menstrual Cycle

Hormone level changes

FSH/LH regulation

Regulates menstrual cycle

Respiratory Rate

High CO2 levels

Increased breathing rate

Normalizes CO2 levels

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is being exclusively breastfed by her mother. During a recent pediatric visit, the mother expresses concern about her milk supply. The pediatrician explains that the infant's feeding patterns contribute to the regulation of milk production. Which physiological concept best describes how the mother’s body responds to the infant’s feeding cues to regulate milk production?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Positive feedback mechanism


 

Explanation:

 

Breastfeeding is an example of a positive feedback mechanism. The initial stimulus amplifies the positive feedback response.

 

Breastfeeding:

 

Examples of positive feedback mechanisms:

 

Mechanism

Description

Outcome

Labour and Childbirth

Stretching of cervix stimulates oxytocin production. Oxytocin release stimulates uterine contractions, which in turn stimulate more oxytocin release.

Amplified contractions leading to childbirth.

Lactation

Baby’s suckling stimulates prolactin and oxytocin release. Prolactin causes enhancement of milk production and oxytocin causes ejection of milk.

Increased milk flow during breastfeeding.

Blood Clotting

Platelets release chemicals that attract more platelets to the site of injury.

Rapid formation of a blood clot to seal the wound.

Nerve Signal Propagation

Depolarisation triggers the opening of sodium channels, causing further depolarisation and more sodium channel opening.

Rapid propagation of the action potential along the nerve fibre.
